Package org.loudouncodes.combinatorics

Class Combinations.KChoose

java.lang.Object
org.loudouncodes.combinatorics.Combinations.KChoose
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterable<int[]>
Enclosing class:
Combinations
public static final class Combinations.KChoose extends Object implements Iterable<int[]>
Sized iterable over k-combinations (with or without repetition).

The default iterator returned by iterator() enumerates in lexicographic order. For the non-repetition model, a Gray-order iterable is available via inGrayOrder().

  • Method Details

    • size

      public long size()
      Returns the number of combinations in this view as a long.

      No repetition: C(n,k). With repetition: C(n+k-1, k). This may overflow for large inputs; use sizeExact() if you need certainty.

      Returns:
      count as best-effort long

    • sizeExact

      public BigInteger sizeExact()
      Returns the exact number of combinations as a BigInteger.

      No repetition: C(n,k). With repetition: C(n+k-1, k).

      Returns:
      exact count

    • inGrayOrder

      public Iterable<int[]> inGrayOrder()
      Returns an Iterable that enumerates the combinations in Gray (revolving-door) order, where each successive combination differs from the previous by swapping exactly one element (symmetric difference size 2).

      Model restriction: Gray order is defined only for combinations without repetition; attempting to call this after withRepetition() will throw. This iterable is independent of the default lexicographic iterator returned by iterator().

      First/last tuples: The sequence begins with the lexicographically first combination [0,1,2,...,k-1] (when k>0) and ends at [n-k, ..., n-1]. For k==0 there is a single empty combination.

      Returns:
      iterable over int[] in Gray order
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - if repetition is enabled

    • iterator

      public Iterator<int[]> iterator()
      Returns an iterator over combinations in lexicographic order.

      Use inGrayOrder() for revolving-door order instead (no repetition only).

      Specified by:
      iterator in interface Iterable<int[]>
